speaker: A
text: Good morning. Today we're diving into a topic that's increasingly dominating headlines: the West's apparent disillusionment with free trade. Donald Trump's tariffs, European concerns over Chinese acquisitions – it all suggests a significant shift. But as our latest article, 'The West's romance with Free Trade is ending. Why?', argues, this isn't a new phenomenon. In fact, for much of its history, the West was militantly anti-free trade, operating a statist mercantilist system from the 1400s onwards. This period saw the rise of powerful, state-backed monopolies like the English East India Company, established in 1600, which fundamentally shaped global commerce through exclusive rights and, often, military might.

speaker: B
text: So, if I'm hearing this correctly, the very idea of 'free trade' as a benevolent, universal good might have been an illusion all along? A convenient narrative rather than an historical reality? It sounds as though free trade was simply a tool, wielded when it suited, rather than a guiding principle.

speaker: A
text: Precisely. Under mercantilism, colonies were treated as captive markets and sources of raw materials. The American colonies, for instance, shipped raw materials to Britain and received manufactured goods in return. This created a wealth drain, one of the key grievances leading to the American War of Independence, as colonists complained about high costs and poor quality of British-made goods. This system was designed to accumulate wealth and power for the home nation, often at the expense of its colonies and trade rivals. It was far from 'free' in the modern sense.

speaker: B
text: And yet, after American independence and the publishing of Adam Smith's 'Wealth of Nations' in 1776, Britain suddenly became the champion of free trade. Was it genuinely a conversion to new intellectual ideals, or was something more pragmatic at play?

speaker: A
text: It was overwhelmingly pragmatic. While Smith and David Ricardo provided the intellectual scaffolding, the real driver was the Industrial Revolution. Britain's mercantilist past had amassed enormous surplus wealth, which funded scientific and technological innovation. By the late 1700s, Britain could produce goods cheaper, better, and in far greater quantities than anyone else. If you're an industrial monopolist, the only thing stopping you from selling globally is other countries' protectionist barriers. So, Britain's shift to militantly pro-free trade was, in essence, an extension of its industrial monopoly.

speaker: B
text: 'Militantly pro-free trade' is a striking phrase. The article mentions Britain using force to break into closed markets. We're talking about gunboat diplomacy, aren't we? The Opium Wars come to mind.

speaker: A
text: Indeed. The Opium Wars, beginning in 1839, are a stark example. China had largely restricted European access, resulting in a significant trade deficit for Britain. The British East India Company began exporting opium from India to China. When China banned and confiscated the opium, Britain retaliated with the Royal Navy, forcing open Chinese markets through the Treaty of Nanking. This wasn't about philosophical ideals; it was about securing and expanding market access for British goods, whatever the cost.

speaker: B
text: So, the pattern is established: a dominant economic power advocates for free trade when it benefits them, and uses force if necessary to ensure that benefit. Britain did it in the 19th century. Then, after the First World War, the US picked up the mantle, pushing for open markets as its own industrial might grew.

speaker: A
text: Precisely. America's large domestic market and manufacturing prowess gave it a similar advantage. Its enthusiasm for free markets persisted until the 1980s, when West German and Japanese products began to challenge US dominance. However, the 'win-win' narrative of free trade was revitalised after the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1989 and gained another burst of enthusiasm when China joined the WTO in 2001. Western and Japanese companies flocked into these new markets, seeking cheap labour and new consumers.

speaker: B
text: That's when many in the West genuinely believed free trade was enriching everyone. Low-cost goods for us, jobs for developing nations. The Ricardian theory of comparative advantage seemed to be playing out perfectly. But what was the hidden cost, even then? The hollowing out of Western manufacturing, the loss of skilled jobs, the dependence on increasingly complex global supply chains?

speaker: A
text: There were significant costs, certainly, often masked by the perceived benefits of cheaper consumer goods and the growth of service industries. However, the true strategic cost began to emerge in the 2010s. China, backed by state support, proved remarkably adept. Western companies had, often voluntarily but sometimes forcibly, transferred decades of know-how and intellectual property through joint ventures. The article highlights this as a 'gigantic trap' – the West effectively trained its primary competitor.

speaker: B
text: So, the West taught China how to play the game, and China not only learned but mastered it, then changed the rules. It reminds me of the historical examples in the article: China once guarded its monopolies on silk, porcelain, and tea fiercely, only to lose them to espionage or reverse-engineering. Now, the roles are reversed.

speaker: A
text: A very astute observation. Those historical parallels are crucial. Christian monks smuggled silkworms out in 552 AD; a German chemist reverse-engineered porcelain in the early 1700s; a British botanist smuggled tea plants out between 1848 and 1851. China lost those monopolies. Now, with its 'Made in China 2025' policy, targeting next-generation industries like AI, robotics, and biotech, China is aggressively moving up the value chain, not just producing low-cost goods but high-value ones too. Their economy grew from $305 billion in 1980 to $12.7 trillion in 2019. It's an unprecedented economic transformation, directly challenging Western industrial supremacy, as we've explored in 'Crisis: Or An Explanation On The Origins Of The Decline Of The West'.

speaker: B
text: And that, then, explains the current Western rethink. Trump's tariffs, Europe's increasingly protectionist stance on critical tech acquisitions. It's not a shift in principle, but a shift in self-interest. Free trade is only great when you're winning, and the West feels it's no longer winning.

speaker: A
text: Exactly. The 'romance' ends when the benefits no longer outweigh the costs, or when the competitive advantage swings decisively to another power. This re-evaluation of free trade is a pragmatic, if painful, response to China's industrial ascent and the challenge it poses to Western economic dominance. It forces a reckoning with the assumptions detailed in our 'The Rise of the West Was Based on Luck. That Has Run Out.' piece.

speaker: B
text: But what are the immediate ramifications of this retreat from free trade? We've built global supply chains based on efficiency and low cost. Ripping that up will surely lead to higher prices for consumers, potentially exacerbating inflation, and creating significant disruption. Are we truly prepared for that?

speaker: A
text: That's the fundamental dilemma. The pursuit of 'reshoring' or 'friend-shoring' production for national security or economic resilience will inevitably increase costs in the short to medium term. Take, for example, the 'renewables and battery revolution' we've covered. China currently dominates the rare earth and battery supply chains. Any attempt to replicate that capacity in the West will be hugely expensive and take years, directly impacting the cost of our energy transition.

speaker: B
text: So, we're looking at a prolonged period of economic nationalism, potentially leading to a more fragmented global economy. Does this not inherently increase geopolitical tensions? Economic competition often precedes, or runs alongside, strategic competition.

speaker: A
text: Undoubtedly. Increased trade barriers and economic decoupling can easily spill over into heightened diplomatic and strategic friction. This aligns with the trends we've discussed in 'Europe Rearms: Why The Continent That Invented Total War Is Spending EUR 800 Billion On Defence.' Economic rivalry feeds into broader security concerns, creating a more volatile global landscape. It suggests a future where economic blocs might become more distinct and potentially confrontational.

speaker: B
text: And the irony is, China, which arguably benefited most from the West's free trade era, is now being accused of being an 'emerging colonial power' itself, as our related article notes. It seems the historical lessons of mercantilism and self-interest have been thoroughly absorbed and adapted by new global players.

speaker: A
text: A very sharp observation. The tools and strategies of global power projection, whether economic or military, tend to be replicated by rising powers. The West, having preached free trade when it suited its industrial dominance, is now confronting a world where others have mastered its own historical playbooks. The critical question for the West now is not just about rebuilding its industrial base, but whether it can navigate this return to protectionism without triggering a broader de-globalisation that ultimately harms its own long-term prosperity and global stability. It's a truly precarious balancing act.
